did.unittitle:
Records of New Perspectives on Caribbean Studies: Toward the 21st Century and Prospects for Caribbean Basin Integration
(Conference held at Hunter College, CUNY, August 28-September 1, 1984)
did.abstract: The conference “New Perspectives on Caribbean Studies: Toward the 21st Century and Prospects for Caribbean Basin Integration,” sponsored by the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM) and the City University of New York (CUNY), was held at Hunter College, CUNY, in New York City, from August 28 – September 1, 1984. The conference provided an interdisciplinary forum for distinguished Caribbeanist scholars, government officials artists, and other participants to reflect on contemporary issues in the Caribbean region. The collection includes correspondence, proposals, conference programs, press releases, abstracts, published and unpublished manuscripts, clippings, articles, journals, photographs, audio and video recordings and transcripts, and an index to the audio and video recordings, transcripts and photographs. The collection contains material duplicated in the Vera D. Rubin Professional Papers.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The records of the conference on "New Perspectives on Caribbean Studies: Toward the 21st Century: New Perspectives for Integration of the Caribbean Basin," were generated by the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM).

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The conference “New Perspectives on Caribbean Studies: Toward the 21st Century and Prospects for Caribbean Basin Integration,” sponsored by the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM) and the City University of New York (CUNY), was held at Hunter College, CUNY, in New York City, from August 28 – September 1, 1984. Vera D. Rubin, Ph.D., founder and director of RISM, Frank McGlynn, Ph.D., Associate Professor of Anthropology at the University of Pittsburgh at Greensburg, and Linda Basch, Ph.D., member of the United Nations Institute for Training and Research (UNITAR), were the principal organizers of the conference. The Caribbean Studies Association (CSA) provided additional collaboration and support. The conference, which received generous support from the Ford Foundation, the National Science Foundation (NSF) and the International Development Research Centre (IDRC) of Canada, attracted 117 participants from the several regions of the Caribbean, the United States of America, Canada and the United Kingdom. Over 350 people registered for the conference, and many others, primarily students, attended without registering.

“Pacem in Maribus” (Peace in the Ocean) was chosen as the theme of the conference, to foster an air of cooperation and inclusion, and to establish a framework for exploring relationships between nation and culture, political economy and scientific progress, social organization and the arts, and agriculture and public health. Critical responses to the recently implemented Caribbean Basin Initiative, a United States program for trade provisions with Caribbean and Latin American countries, shaped the primary goals of the conference: to revisit, review and reorient long-standing theoretical issues associated with Caribbean studies. The conference was designed to stimulate direct engagement among scholars working in different countries addressing theoretical and methodological issues with an interdisciplinary focus on the region as an integrated whole.

More than one hundred prominent Caribbean scholars, government officials and policymakers engaged in a scholarly examination of the economic, political and social issues particular to the Caribbean region. Notable speakers included Michael Manley, former Prime Minister of Jamaica and leader of the People’s National Party (PNP), novelist and poet George Lamming, and anthropologist M. G. Smith.

Conference sessions consisted of presented papers and panel discussions. Participants interacted as discussants and co-chairs, and took part in question-and-answer exchanges with audience members. In addition to the scheduled sessions, there was a series of informal panel discussions, referred to as “roundtable sessions,” in which two to six scholars discussed significant contemporary issues in the Caribbean. Roundtable sessions were video-recorded with the intention of producing short educational videos on Caribbean issues to be used throughout the CUNY system. Guided by framing questions, roundtable participants reflected on seven main topics: history of the region, artistic culture and politics, the “crisis” caused by multiple development policies in the Caribbean, transnational oil companies in Trinidad, obstacles to socioeconomic and political change, intraregional and international migration, and Haitian political and cultural issues.

Additional recorded highlights of the conference included an awards ceremony for outstanding achievement in the creative arts hosted by Donna Shalala, former President of Hunter College. Award recipients were Calypso singer Mighty Sparrow (Slinger Francisco) of Trinidad and Tobago, author George Lamming of Barbados, and sculptor Edna Manley of Jamaica, whose award was accepted by her son Michael Manley on her behalf.
Unpublished Conference Address, Vera D. Rubin, August 29, 1984 (Series XI)
At Hunter, quarterly newsletter No. 2, October 1984.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The records of the conference “New Perspectives on Caribbean Studies: Toward the 21st Century and Prospects for Caribbean Basin Integration” span the years 1979 to 2008, consist of approximately 17.5 linear feet (29 boxes), and include correspondence, mailing lists, published and unpublished manuscripts, abstracts, curricula vitae, advertisements, annual reports of foundations, artwork, flyers, posters, greeting cards, book reviews, articles, journals, brochures, clippings, conference programs and proposals, maps, press releases, photographs, audio and video recordings, transcripts and ephemera. The material has been organized as 16 series (see Arrangement, p. 6). Specific details of chronological or alphabetical arrangement are included in the scope and content note for each series.

Series I. Correspondence includes correspondence with many prominent government officials that laid the groundwork for the conference. Series IV. Publicity documents the organizers’ efforts gain support and to promote interest in the conference, and includes meeting minutes, flyers and conference programs, and post-conference articles published by Hunter College.
Series II and III were removed from the collection. (See “Separated Materials” for details.)

Series VI. Conference Participant Files contains correspondence between Vera D. Rubin and leading contemporary Caribbeanists. Many of these individuals served as co-chairs, participants, or observers at the conference. The files also include manuscripts and articles written by or about conference participants, previously published book reviews, original artwork, greeting cards, invitations, curricula vitae and posters.
Additional post-conference reportage can be found in Series VII. Clippings, and photographic materials in Series VIII show highlights of the conference.

Series XI, XII and XIII contain published and unpublished manuscripts (Mss.) covering an extensive range of issues impacting the Caribbean Basin in the 1980s: social stratification, cultural identity, religion, the effects of migration, the status of health systems, agricultural development, science and technology, and 'political' music and other politicized forms of creative expressions. These series include conference presentations and post-conference submissions for publication. Following Dr. Rubin's untimely death in February 1985, plans for the publication of the conference proceedings by Yale University Press continued until 1987, but ultimately were not realized; Series XII. Yale University Press Manuscripts contains manuscripts prepared for this publication. In the interim, Frank McGlynn published a select number of original manuscripts in December 1986 in the journal Third World Studies (see Series XIII. Published Manuscripts).

Series XVII. Digitized Audio and Video Recordings and Transcripts contains a three-volume duplicate original manuscript produced for institutional circulation by the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM) and InterAmericas, programs of The Reed Foundation. “New Perspectives on Caribbean Studies: Toward the 21st Century and Prospects for Caribbean Basin Integration” Transcripts of the Audio and Video Recordings, edited by Mercedes Duff with Danielle Davenport and Jane Gregory Rubin, is comprised of transcripts and digitized copies of the analog audio and video recordings in Series XVI, prints of video stills and selected photographs from Series VIII, and an index to the audio and video transcripts, photographs, and video stills. Spanish and Haitian Creole audio and video material was transcribed and translated by Danielle Davenport and James Larèche.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records of the conference, "New Perspectives on Caribbean Studies: Toward the 21st Century" have been arranged in the following series. Please note that this collection does not contain a Series II or a Series III.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Written or typed originals-correspondence, (ALS, TLS) signed by notable individuals, have been removed from the collection and replaced with Xerox photocopies. The originals are located in the Originals Correspondence Binder. Series II and Series III contained grant funding, accounting and financial records from the RISM Corporate Records and were returned to The Reed Foundation to be housed with the RISM Corporate Records. One box of duplicate material has been removed from the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Some restricted materials pertaining mainly to finances, internal administration, and private information remain at the Reed Foundation and are closed to researchers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: .5 linear feet (1 box) arranged chronologically. The series consists of incoming and outgoing correspondence generated by RISM and CUNY conference organizers. Papers in this series highlight planning details and initial outreach efforts to potential participants. Items of interest include correspondence and a report concerning visa restrictions that impacted some conference participants (see Folder 4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1.0 linear feet (2 boxes), arranged chronologically. This series documents the efforts of RISM and CUNY conference organizers to gain support and promote interest in the conference. Included are minutes, conference programs, correspondence, mailing lists, form letters and invitations. Publicity materials include advertisements, press releases and conference announcements. A number of unique conference flyers and conference brochures are also included (see Box 4, folder 1 below, and Series XIV. Oversized Materials, Box 25). Hunter College newsletters provide a unique post-conference report (see Box 5, folders 29 - 32). For additional post-conference coverage, see Series VII. Clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note:
scopecontent.p: Approximately 3.5 linear feet (7 boxes), arranged alphabetically by last name. Representing the largest series in the collection, these files were maintained for individuals who presented papers, served as co-chairs or were discussants. The files include correspondence, personal greeting cards, abstracts, curriculum vitae, newsletters, journals and clippings. Items of note include Vera D. Rubin's opening remarks (see Box 12, Folder 130) and articles, book reviews and earlier writings by and about conference presenters. For the original manuscript papers delivered at the 1984 conference, see Series XI. Conference Manuscripts. Duplicate copies of the manuscripts, taken from the Library of Caribbean Research, are listed in the Appendix. A select number of these papers were also part of a planned publication (see Series XII. Yale Press Manuscripts and subsequently published (see Series XIII. Published Manuscripts).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note:
scopecontent.p: .5 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. This series, which consists of clippings from U.S. and Caribbean papers, has been organized as three subseries. Subseries a. relates to grant funding, Subseries b. contains articles on a wide range of international topics, and Subseries c. consists of post-conference articles. Oversized clippings have been transferred to Series XV. Oversized materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note:
scopecontent.p: Approximately 1.0 linear feet (1 box, 1 binder). This series is comprised of 108 negatives, 3 contact sheets, 69 photographic prints, photocopies of 5 contact sheets, and one disc containing 180 image files in TIFF format. All images originate from black and white 35 mm film. The disc and the photographic prints are located in a separate binder labeled Notebook 14A. The contents of the disc are described in Subseries a., b., and c., and the photographic prints are described in Subseries d. Subseries a. contains digitized copies of the negatives in Folder 4; Subseries b. contains digitized copies of contact sheets in Folder 3; Subseries c. contains digitized copies of the photographic prints in Subseries d. Images in Subseries a., b., c., and d. have been arranged by conference session, and assigned consecutive ID numbers, e.g. “CC84-01.” Digitized copies of photographic prints and corresponding original photographic prints have been assigned identical ID numbers.

Series XI. Conference Manuscripts (unpublished) June 1984-January 1985

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note:
scopecontent.p: 2.0 linear feet (4 boxes). Arranged in order of presentation (see conference programs, Box 16, Folder 1). Although some Mss. titles differ from those listed in the conference programs, this series consists of original conference manuscripts. Highlights include the opening remarks by Vera D. Rubin (see Folder 3), original art work, the closing address by former prime minister Michael Manley and papers associated with the award ceremony. Based on the correspondence and tally sheets in this series, some Mss. were revised or formalized after the conference for publication. Several Mss. were not submitted.

Series XII. Yale University Press Manuscripts (unpublished) June 1984 - May 1987

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note:
scopecontent.p: 1.5 linear feet (3 boxes). Arranged as chapters of the proposed publication (see Box 20, Folder 1). This series consists of a select number of conference manuscripts that were revised and reorganized for a planned submission to Yale University Press. Although the planned publication did not materialize, the papers in this series include chapter title pages, indicated in italics, lists of submissions and revised manuscripts.

Series XIII. Published Manuscripts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note:
scopecontent.p: .5 linear feet (1 box). Arranged chronologically. This series consists of a select number of manuscripts presented at the conference (see Series XI. Conference Manuscripts). Edited by Frank McGlynn, then Associate Professor of Anthropology at the University of Pittsburgh at Greensburg, the papers were included in a special issue entitled "The Social Anthropology of the Contemporary Caribbean" published by the journal Third World Studies. Additional highlights in this series include a draft tribute and partial list bibliographic publications by Vera D. Rubin, written and compiled by Frank McGlynn for the preface (see Folder 1).

Series XVI. Audio and Video Recordings, August 1984 - March 1985

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note:
scopecontent.p: Approximately 2 linear feet (2 Paige boxes). This series contains 26 videotapes, 26 digibeta copies of the videotapes as well as 26 DVD copies of videotapes, 60 original audiotapes and 60 CD copies of original audiotapes. All tapes are arranged in numerical sequence. The videotapes are labeled with the prefix "68768" followed by the tape number (i.e.68768/1). The inventory treats the second number as the tape number. Series XVII. Digitized Audio and Video Recordings and Transcripts contains digitized copies of these audio and video recordings, transcripts, and indices to the audio and video transcripts.
